theme.title: The bass clef
theme.para: The F clef on the fourth line, also named 'bass clef', is represented by the following symbol:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef F)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (barline double noVisible) )))

theme.para: The bass clef assigns the F note to the 4th line, as shown in following picture:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef F)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''F note'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n f3 w) (barline double noVisible) )))

theme.para: As a result, the staff lines and spaces get automatically assigned to consecutive notes, as shown in the next score:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef F)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''G'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n g2 q) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n a2 q) (text ''B'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n b2 q) (text ''C'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n c3 q) (text ''D'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n d3 q) (text ''E'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n e3 q) (text ''F'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n f3 q) (text ''G'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n g3 q) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n a3 q) (barline double noVisible) )))

theme.para: In the bass clef the first upper leger line corresponds to the central C note (C4), represented in G clef on the first lower leger line:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''C note'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n c4 w) (barline double) (clef F) (spacer 20) (text ''C note'' dx:0 dy:-20) (n c4 w) (barline double) )))

theme.para: By using both the G clef and the F clef and two leger lines a range of five octaves can be comfortably represented, as shown in the following score:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Staff.UpperLegerLines.Displacement 20) (opt Render.SpacingMethod fixed) (opt Render.SpacingValue 40) (instrument (staves 2) (musicData (clef treble p1) (clef bass p2) (key C) (time 4 4 noVisible) (text ''G'' dx:0 dy:200) (n g2 w p2) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:200) (n a2 w) (text ''B'' dx:0 dy:200) (n b2 w) (text ''C'' dx:0 dy:200) (n c3 w) (text ''D'' dx:0 dy:200) (n d3 w) (text ''E'' dx:0 dy:200) (n e3 w) (text ''F'' dx:0 dy:200) (n f3 w) (text ''G'' dx:0 dy:200) (n g3 w) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:200) (n a3 w) (text ''B'' dx:0 dy:200) (n b3 w) (text ''C'' dx:0 dy:200) (n c4 w) (text ''D'' dx:0 dy:200) (n d4 w p1) (text ''E'' dx:0 dy:200) (n e4 w) (text ''F'' dx:0 dy:200) (n f4 w) (text ''G'' dx:0 dy:200) (n g4 w) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:200) (n a4 w) (text ''B'' dx:0 dy:200) (n b4 w) (text ''C'' dx:0 dy:200) (n c5 w) (text ''D'' dx:0 dy:200) (n d5 w) (text ''E'' dx:0 dy:200) (n e5 w) (text ''F'' dx:0 dy:200) (n f5 w) (barline end) )))

part.title: Listen and take notice of the differences
part.para: In this lesson we are going to start reading the bass clef, while practising the rhythmic patterns studied in previous lessons. We will start reading notes A3, B3 and C4:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Render.SpacingMethod fixed) (opt Render.SpacingValue 60) (instrument (musicData (clef bass)(key C) (time 4 4 noVisible) (text ''A'' dx:0 dy:-20) (n a3 w) (text ''B'' dx:0 dy:-20) (n b3 w) (text ''C'' dx:0 dy:-20) (n c4 w) (barline end) )))
